(Im reposting this because instead of addressing the issue at hand this business reported my review due to the fact that I made the mistake of offering alternatives. So I'm reposting and removing anything that is against yelp policy. But this is my honest experience at this establishment)  I'm writing this day's after my incident at Harlem Hookah. I wanted to write this from a place of clarity and not anger. I'm a patron of Harlem Hookah. I went the first day they opened, celebrated NYE here, and have on multiple occasions brought siblings and friends here. I've even had the opportunity to meet one of the owners. The cocktails have never been great but they have excellent champagne. Their hookah is overpriced but it's done perfectly. And it has always felt good to be surrounded by people from the neighborhood especially on game nights. On Saturday 26th April, around 2 AM, I called from two blocks away to check on the status of the wait & or line. I was told if I arrived quickly I should have luck because a few guests were leaving and there was no Line. I usually NEVER go on weekends because I am not a fan of the wait, the chaos etc. But we got lucky, there was no line and within minutes 9 guests left, followed by 2 more, and another 2. I had my younger sister with me and we both needed to use the facilities. I asked how long, I was told he'll let me know when he knows. I asked if we could please use the facilities and come back and wait in line. I offered for us to go one at a time. And pretty much begged this man to have some understanding and empathy for two women, one of which comes here often, and are literally just waiting for tables to get wiped down and prepared. Instead of perhaps having the courtesy of checking with the host, manager, he chose instead to get aggressive, show no empathy. The more I asked, the more aggressive and scary and disrespectful he got. I called and Uber and we called it a night. His energy, his movement all of it unsettled me and scared me. This is a business. All it would have taken is to be hospitable, inquire within if he could make an exception for said policy, or even attempt to expedite our seating. Instead he decides to keep us out there longer. I work in the hospitality industry and the first thing I did is scope out the space before standing in line, even before 13 people walked out there were three bar stools empty. This was a vindictive act, a show of power, and an act that is utterly despicable. The fact that it's a policy to keep guests who are waiting to enter, spend money at your establishment waiting when they desperately need to use the facilities is messed up. I am a woman, who has spent countless evenings at Harlem Hookah, who tips generously and spends. I am not a person who is attempting to rob you; or do drugs in your restroom or whatever other twisted logic was use to implement this. Just because this establishment is in Harlem doesn't mean a black owned business needs to take these kind of measures as if we are barbarians or incapable of stepping into your lounge, using the stupid facilities and respectful coming back out and standing in line. We are people. Treat us like it. The way the owners run this business and the people you hire to greet guests and allow them in... needs work. Or better yet move your business elsewhere maybe then you'll feel safe enough to allow two harmless woman to use your restroom while you make them wait just because you want to, not because you need to. Because there is this d'illusion that having a line for a half empty lounge is cool, or more attractive. It's not. Treat people from this neighborhood like people instead of animals. Because that's exactly how this door man made me feel. The way he treated me was dirty, and the most racist thing I've ever felt from my own people. It was disgusting. Days after this incident i still feel utterly dirty for having to beg a man, with the same skin tone as me, from the same neighborhood to have some understanding. To be this embarrassed and treated as if I wasn't a person. It's just sad. We get this everyday in this country, we don't need it from our own. Harlem Hookah, I will obviously never ever come here again. But please don't mistake this review on some lack of understanding of how a lounge is run, I'm well aware of the issue of capacity and the need to keep guests in a line when necessary. This evening it was not. You were not at capacity as 13 people walked out and there were vacant seats at your bar even before those people exited the establishment. You could have been hospitable and empathetic and management could have been present and monitoring the door man you hire. So please don't berate me or insult me. It's better to say nothing then to insult a patron that was not treated well at your establishment and simply expressing their grievances.

Now, I wish I could give a higher rating, but this rating is more so about my experience with the manger rather than the venue or the support staff.  I decided to select this place for my graduation get together mainly for the decor and the location.  I've been here for happy hour which was a good experience.  I got to speak to the hostess that day to inquire about making reservations for a large party (20 ppl) for a graduation celebration.  The hostess told me the policy stating that a $100 nonrefundable deposit was required and in order to be seated the hostess stated that all or most of the party must be present, most meaning at least 15-16 of the party.  I verified with the hostess and spent time speaking to her that day and spoke with another hostess on the phone who stated the same information.   I finally decided to book reservations, I had to call to make the reservation over the phone and at this time I spoke with the manager Fany.  When we initially spoke I wanted to verify what I was told by the hostess, the manager informed me it was completely false!  She stated all of my party must be present, I told her I spoke with someone on 3 occasions and they told me the same thing on all occasions. She asked me who the person was so she can have a meeting with them, I wasn't about to cost no one their job. Although Fany wasn't necessarily rude, she was not compassionate and she did not have a welcoming attitude and she definitely was not accommodating.  She stated that even if 1 person was late or did not show up it will forfeit my reservation as she stated it becomes very booked or busy. I was disappointed and tried to explain to her that wasn't the information I was given prior and secondly you mean to tell me 1 person short you would ruin someone's plans and reservation.  Ultimately I did book because I liked the venue that much, however based on her demand and strict policy I was overwhelmed and stress about my reservation putting pressure on my guests I wanted to attend.  I even lied to guest that my reservation was earlier than it really was to assure everyone was present and on time, which I would've did in the first place but I was more diligent in my request than normal.  Fast forward to the day of, not only was my whole party not all present at the scheduled time, they did allow us to seat with 2-3 ppl not present at the time, they eventually came shortly after of course but the stress Fany put on me was for NOTHING!!!!! I had a good experience there but I was a little embarrassed about forcing everyone to rush and Informing them of the strict policy when ultimately there was no need to do so.  Not only that but the place was not "busy" with out my party being there.  We were the bulk of the clientele and they got a good amount of business from us. However I would never make reservations here again nor will I make recommendations to others.  I strongly suggest you don't stress your customers out or else you will lose business, be sure all staff are on the same page with the policies and you guys should rethink some of the policies for business and reputation.
